number of helpful: 733 of 834 people (88%) found this review helpful17 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
												REVIEW OF RECENT GAME CHANGES by ALVARAKK, 16/01/2014 (updated 09/09/2014)MY BACKGROUNDI started playing DnT with first released on Facebook about one year ago and I have been playing regularly since. I was admitted to play-testing group and granted access to the developer's test-server. I am a pro-player, with some 5,000+ ranked PvP matches and reached top 3 ranking position consecutively in the last three PvP seasons and last stats show me at highest KDR (Kill-to-Death Ratio) in the game. I am currently ranked #9 in PvP season 4.Trust me when I tell you, Dragons and Titans is NOT WORTH your time or money. .* The game patch of 01/04/2014 introduced lock-on auto-aim which drastically changed the movement controls in the game, made several dragon combos obsolete, and completely removed the need for players to learn and master their maneuvering and aiming skills. In the recent months Wyrmbyte carried on to dumb-down the game in hopes of attracting more players -- ultimately failing in that too as player numbers in Multiplayer PvP at peak times of the day stand at around 400 now (compare that to DOTA2 or LOL where you have tens of thousands). They reduced the competitive aspect of PvP into a witless and uninspired routine of holding down the fire button and moving your mouse back and forth to control the firing range. Teamplay and coordination have been rendered obsolete in lieu of a contest where players compete only on who can dish out more damage fastest. The advantages of precise timing and tactical thinking have been stripped out of competitive PvP and matches have descended into routine of blindly rushing the opponents in the hopes of out-damaging them. Outcomes are primarily decided on what combos individual players picked up, which is random and unpredictable.* The update of 10/06/2014 continued the steady decline changing the mechanics of the matching-system.-Teams are now truly and completely random and unpredictable. The most shocking change is that the pre-match setup stage was removed, which is where you used to be able to get a minute's worth of chat with the 4 teammates the game picked up for you and discuss combos and tactics. Now, you are plunged directly into match with no opportunity to plan and prepare.-To make things worse, players can not choose or predict what map is going to be played (there are 3, each a completely different mode of play), so they don't get can't pick a suitable combo and enter matches blind and ill-prepared.- The other drastic change was that the restrictions on selection of dragon and weapons was removed. In the past players could only pick a weapon and dragon that was not already in use by one of their teammates and generally whoever was first to click it, got it and mostly refused to relinquish it. Whilst this caused a lot of heated pre-match bickering and some truly foul behavior between teammates, it also forced players to think about what combos best supported and complemented that of the rest of their team. This is no longer the case and players have foregon support roles and invariably stick with the cookie-cutter combos that give them the biggest DPS advantage. This change has also taken away from the formerly enjoyable variety offered by DnT 's myriad of choices, and along with it the need for new players to familiarize themselves with all weapons/dragons and take time to learn their strengths and weaknesses. To illustrate the point, most matches now include a bland carbon-copy selection of combos, with most players equipping Winter Floe and Skyburst and riding either an Imperial or Gemtalon.- In the same stroke, Wyrmbyte hammered-in the last nail to DnT's coffin by preventing players from teaming-up with more than one player. Thus, they dashed all hopes of players being able to form into clans or guilds and fighting it out in Full 5v5s. We are now left to suffer matches that are little more than a frustrating lottery and where skill and experience have scant impact on the outcome.OTHER ISSUESDisappointingly, Wyrmbyte continues to ignore feedback from their play-testers and experienced players alike, resulting in a completely unbalanced PvP and proving to the gaming industry that their diminutive team is just too amateurish and does not have what it takes to deliver an enjoyable gaming experience. Also characteristic of Wyrmbyte is their complete inability to improve and fix their game code, where the blight of bugs seems completely out of control. Major bugs that have been in existence at the early stages of the beta testing, persist still with no indication from Wyrmbyte as to whether they have any plans to sort them out. The introductions of STEAM client failed to stem the constant flow of speed-hacking cheaters that continue to abuse the game and take all fun out of it for genuine players. On top of that, new game issues and exploits are cropping up at an alarming rate and each new game update from Wyrmbyte is a guaranteed source of new and persistent problems.CONCLUSIONSSomewhere along the way Dragons and Titans drifted off-course and lost all sight of becoming a balanced and challenging 5v5 arena and is now being precariously carried-away into the chaotic waters of a mediocre free-for-all. The spectacular dragon themes and above-standard quality of art alone fail to sustain player interest and unsurprisingly their numbers are dwindling daily. This game had promising potential in its early life, which was however ultimately squandered by Wyrmbyte who failed time and again to improve and polish their product. RECOMMENDATIONThis game will disappoint and frustrate you. Stay away from it.There are better free MOBAs out there.UPDATEAs of 09/09/2014 there is still no option to choose map or predict which one will be played. No pre-match team screen to discuss tactics. Speed-hackers continue to dominate the game and the cheaters are completely out of control. Whoever in Wyrmbyte is making decisions on game development should hang their head in shame and just leave the gaming industry forever. So much fail.

Posted: November 12, 2014
												This game was quite dissapointing, I did buy the titans pass because it is fun for awhile, but it lacks many things that are standard in moba's these days. Advantages:- Dragons are awesome and well designed artistically - It's fun- graphics are average- lots of gamemodes and updatesdisavantages:- you can't pick your dragon with your team, which is just horrible for a MOBA, you can end up with 5 supports or none, you can also have the same dragon as somebody else, this is very bad designed and makes the game unbalanced. - you can't pick your game mode, it is rotated by the server, and you find out what gamemode you are playing after you select your dragon, some are better then others in certain maps. This is again, very poor design for a MOBA and even a basic MOBA needs this. - Developers reasoning for bad design choices is that there isn't enough players to allow for people selecting there maps, this is very counter inuitive, because I'm sure more people would play if you could select your dragon as a team and chose the map. Which brings me to my next point. - Small player base that isn't growing. - global chatroom has people of all languges speaking in it, it should be seperated by language as you cannot communicate properly- the community that there is have been quite immature at times and quite toxic, there is only a few exceptions. - lack of depth in gameplayI do not recomend this game, but since it's free, you should try to see if you have fun with it, It still can be very fun at times but I would suggest if you wanted to play a dragon in a MOBA, you should go and play Jakiro on dota 2. (EDIT: OR WINTER WYVERN)

												The game is great, don't get me wrong.. It just lacks structure in the shop aspects of the game, the prices change frequently and sometimes get removed entirely. When the time comes to buy a new dragon and or weapon, you don't buy the individual one you need for a certain job, you get what the random eggs/chests give you and that's it. This completely ruins the strategic aspect of the game entirely. Making it very hard to create a decent build or get the "most efficient" combination of weapon and dragon. Earning the in-game currency 'crystal' takes ages, especially when you consider the chances of receiving an exceptionaly less useful weapon/dragon.Pairing with your already non-combinable combinations of weapon/dragons you may already own.I give this a 3/5 rating based on the fact that you can't buy what you want with your hard earned crystals that take time to farm.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												This game has been out for some time. The more you play and the longer you play the more perks for your dragon and you. That part is good. There is a single player, co-op and pvp. There are only 3 maps so single player gets dull quick. Co-op allows you to play with other players on your team but the AI is relatively weak so they get steam rolled pretty quick. The only real joy would appear to be pvp. The matching system in pvp however makes it so as a new player you might be playing against very high level dragons. You will be killed easily and quickly by them, often. As such, while you may occasionally have a good game in pvp. Largely you will be used by high levels to bolster their kill ratios. There also appears to be a fair amount of hacking going on that seems to be unchecked. All in all, it appears like a very fun game but as a new player don't expect easy or enjoyable, you will be a wonderful target.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
												Don't get baited.This game has the worst tutorial ever created. The controls are clunky and you have to jump through hoops to play 5v5 pvp.It is terribly unpolished and not worth the time. Dragons don't move by the standard right click to location they follow the mouse cursor, you press spacebar to fly backwards like a hummingbird and each dragon gets 2 skills only. You bring a weapon from the cash shop into battle that gives you 2 other abilities.There are tons of dragons to choose from but the game doesn't feel like it has a core element. There are dragons that clearly outrank others in terms of innate abilities. The games in game graphics are worse than they are in screenshots. The screenshots for this game seem to have been touched up to give it a better presentation.Comparing this to other MOBA/ARTS games out there, I rather play any other one than this.Edit: I have played a couple of multiplayer games as you can see to my play time; it’s really a cluster♥♥♥♥ of things going on. The Map isn't that intuitive given the movement limitations and controls.I've used a golem type dragon that fires boulders that ricochet when they hit an enemy or wall. Together with a Purple rod that allowed me to set mines and automatically teleport me to the nearest gold roost.During many exchanges I noticed players talk in the lobby about the weapon they purchased from the shop given them a distinct advantage.The main problem with control is the fact that all of your abilities directly are targeted at wherever your mouse cursor is. What causes the rift is that your dragon also follows the cursor religiously for movement. So when fighting you have to constantly be flying backward or standing still to get the 8 way directional aiming to do what you want.Standing still in a fight is never the answer, Flying backward slows down your movement considerably to almost about half. If the controls where polished a bit more and maybe rework the 5v5 map to better compliment the fact we are using dragons more it could have been a good niche market.There are tons of dragons to pick from and weapons to accompany them, variety is good. With the already oversaturation of the ARTS/MOBA market I can't recommend this game over anything else in its current state.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
												The game seems okay but a lot mechanics don't really work for me.First of all there will be INSANE amounts of grind, absolutely insane. Each stage seems to have 10 levels, each level has 5 objectives to complete, three of the five objectives require specific dragons and items to be completed so you will more than likely have to buy them with real money if you want to complete the objectives.The reason you might want to complete the objectives is because they will give you rewards (like a new dragon if you complete all 5 objectives in all 10 levels, so 150 total "levels" * an average of 7 minutes per level = 1050 minutes/17.5 hours total assuming you finish them all in your first try, which you wont). Again, this is a huge grind if you want to do the single player missions to try and get new dragons or items or whatever else they may give you.Game difficulty seems to ramp up very quickly as well. I'm barely on act 1-5 (undead crypt?) and it's pretty much impossible to complete with all the dragons they throw at you. I opened one door and 5-6 very powerful dragons spawned. I used all 3 revives and still wasn't able to kill them.I haven't kept track of how much money you get per completed mission but it's very very little. Half way done with "act 1" and I only have about 400 gold or whatever the currency is. To purchase a dragon pack (3 random dragons) you need 5000, to purchase weapon pack (3 random weapons) you need 2500 I believe. Steam says I've played 2.2 hours, remove about 15-20 minutes to account for the tutorial and you can see how slowly you earn money.The microtransactions SEEM pretty reasonable compared to other games but I haven't spent too much time looking at and comparing everything. Some dragons are 3-5 dollars which isn't bad.The mechanics that don't work or that I'm simply not a fan of is the movement and combat. Most of the time it's just a huge mess of enemies clustered together flying around each other trying to hit you. My only recommendation would be a complete overhaul of the controls where you use WASD (or whatever keys you bind) to move and have the dragon shoot where your mouse cursor points (restricted to 140-180 degrees of the direction you're facing, otherwise it would just be silly). Whether the developers are interested in putting all this work to change it, I don't know.Options are terrible. I wanted to lower the volume and you can only toggle both the sounds and music on or off. You can change your resolution and that's about it. It feels like a really terrible mobile port or browser based game. The game has potential with the idea but it's not really worth investing any time or money into at this point. It is free though so by all means try it, but if you have bandwidth limits or something then I wouldn't recommend it (although it's only 300ish mb which is nice).If the grind is lessened and the controls are done better I think it would definitely be worth investing some time into. I have not played the PvP yet so any sort of balance or matchmaking issues are obviously not covered in this.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
												Before I say anything else, let me be clear about one thing.  This game IS good for someone who is new to MOBAs.  Playing around on it can be fun, and you can have a good time just pounding on the computers if you want.  I like the way that you can mix the activatable abilities of your dragon by swapping in different weapons.  It's a feature I haven't seen in the other MOBAs I have played.  The weapons usually don't provide abilities that are broken with any specific dragons, so the balancing on it isn't too bad.However, if you are familiar with MOBAs, you'll only really play this one when you don't have access to your favorites.  The monetization of this game leaves a lot to be desired.  I get that they are trying to make money off of their product, but they didn't have to make it into some sort of CCG for dragons and weapons.  It's nice that they provide a daily login bonus, and that every 5 days you get another free (random) dragon, but the amount of gems that it takes to get the booster pack of dragons or weapons is pretty high, and you don't even have the option of picking out a specific one of either.  They love to point out how many gems you would have earned after each match if you had just been willing to spend the money on a Titan Pass, too, which I find to be very annoying.All in all, this game shows a lot of potential, but it's just not living up to it for those of us who are already familiar with MOBAs.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2016
												Dragons and Titans. Let's talk. I saw this game, saw dragons, and thought "Well, why not try it out. It's free so let's see what it's about." And thus learned this is what a MOBA is called. For what it is, if you have no experience with any MOBAs it really is good. It's a great "Get your feet wet" kinda game. Hell, I spent over 850 hours playing it so it must be good right? Right?! Well, frankly, if there was a "neutral" button, I'd put it. If I had made my review a year ago, it'd be an absolute thumbs up reccomendation. As of now, I can't. It pains me to say it because this game is boat loads of fun. Was, I should say...First, let's discuss how you begin: You start off with the tutorial, and afterwards get a dragon egg pack. There are like, 30 dragons and the egg packs are random. You could get x3 of the same dragon, x3 support, x3 damage, or just x3 crap dragons you suck at. It's 100% random. You can get more egg packs for 5,000 gems which are the currency in game, but it takes a while. The first egg pack you get is free. I've heard stories of people starting out with x3 support dragons which suck for a new player. But again. Random.So, if you start out with dragons that are support or dragons that just arn't your playstyle, etc...you're going to have a tough time starting out. Did I mention 5,000 gems takes a while to get? Sure you can buy individual dragons, with REAL money, but....do you if you JUST are trying out a game?RNG aside, you start out now. There are 4 acts for the main storyline for single player, single player for the 4 MOBA maps, co-op vs ai, and pvp. You can only play the first act as the others are locked until you pay 20$ for the Titan Pass. I never got it. Payed for a few dragons though when they had a sale though. Alright, now for game play. You can choose a dragon and weapon combo. Some are better than others and are overused in PvP but that's besides the point. Each dragon/weapon has two abilities, some passive, others active depending on the weapon/dragon. Traditional MOBA however. You also have Runes which in truth are the main game changer. You have rune pages that you can customise for your game style. Each rune can be upgraded, but...RNG TIME! You need x3 t1 runes OF THE SAME to upgrade to t2, and x3 OF THE SAME t2 runes to upgrade to t3. How do you get t1 runes? A random t1 rune pack for 250 gems! And there's a super difference between a player with a rune page full of 15 t3 damage increase runes to a player with no runes, even if they have a same combo. Oh, and each pvp match gives you about 30-100 gems on average, with 100 being the cap. Co-op gives 20-40 and single player about 10-25. So, those 5,000 needed gems start looking harder and harder to achive. Sure the Titan Pass increases your gem income per match but....20$.Dragons are similar with you needing x3 t1 of the same dragons for t2, etc. But with random dragon egg packs....Weapons can be fordged to be better using reagents you find in game so that's easy to do. You get more weapons for 2,500 gems...but it's a RANDOM weapon pack that you MAY easily get more of the same weapon if you're unlucky and more than one weapon is 100% useless.But through all this it's a super fun game! It's engaging, you WANT to upgrade your dragons...you WANT to succeed for fun! So why not the reccomendation thumbs up?Well, let's discuss why I stopped playing. Remember when I said that Runes can make or break a game? I would have a full rune page of damage runes mix with T2/T3 runes and deal so little damage it's pathetic. Then randomly, mid match (Sometimes never) I suddenly deal massive damage. With a page full of Cooldown runes, I notice my cooldown's aren't getting reduced. Then suddenly, mid match my cooldowns half they were. My rune pages weren't always active. So, I send in a ticket like normal people and figure I'll stop playing for a while till it gets sorted out. That was a year ago. No comments back.Also, there were no updates to the game in over 6-7 months. So, while it was (And is if the bugs don't kick in) a super fun game, until the bugs get worked out, I don't see much more redemption for the game.Perhaps in due time I can update this and say it's back in business. But right now, it pains me to say...No.

number of helpful: 23 of 23 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
												Spent a lot of my time on this game, so I think I am eglible for a review...This game was first released for playing only through Facebook, and those were the days the game actually shined. There was a (relatively) decent amount of players of all kinds and from all around the world, and also updates were applied on a daily basis... It was easy to lose your entire day to playing Dragons And Titans.After about a year after it came out, Wyrmbyte made a Facebook > Steam transfer which seemed like a happy deal for a lot of enthusiastic players, but also made the Facebook version less and less playable, gradually. In the first days of the Steam version there was a lot of lag since they didn't separate players on Facebook from the ones on Steam, but that wasn't as much of a problem as the Facebook version being unplayable.That said, the playerbase halved, since a lot of players were only people who enjoyed quickly logging into Facebook and having a quick game before going to work/school/lunch/...funeral?, and didn't have the time or will to go through the hassle of installing the Steam version.After a year of basically Steam-only DnT, the playerbase started to shrink even more.Since there was a lot of raging and reporting other players (clear example of a MOBA community huh?), the devs of the game decided to try and make the 10yr olds playing happy:  - basically added aimbot, removed any skill required  - removed map selection  - allowed more than one number of same dragon or weapon selected in the same team  - removed microtransactions and added a macro (some would think that'd be good but oh boy how wrong those would be! Christ it's supposed to be a F2p, and with unlocking EVERYTHING for the buyers for a year, while also making them earn 4X THE XP AND CRYSTALS (currency) it doesn't really thrive to remain f2p friendly.) The macrotransaction also nullified all your microtransactions from before, so despite the hundreds some had spent, they had to pay 20$ to get what they already payed for.  - made buying dragons and weapons random, no possibility of picking  - started adding new dragons and weapons on almost a weekly basis, but those were just so unoriginal and you could see the uncanny resemblance not just with some features from other games, but also copies of other DnT Dragons, with changed names!!  - there was even an ARAM map which they at some point decided to make more child-appealing, so it just became ... AM (all middle)?...To summarize, if you're looking to play, consider this:PROS:- free- visually decent- 20 min is considered an extra long game - fast paced and intense- a fair amount of dragons and weapons to choose fromCONS:- macrotransaction for 4x progress- no map selection- no skill required to play (should this be a pro?)- no victory tactics or strategy- no team roles- no teamwork required- no 3+ teams assembling- player base capped at ~250 (can't reach 300 despite unhumane efforts of Jesus, Buddha, Cthullu and FSM)- no in-match stat altering [with items or such] (since games are so quick,this may not be a major problem but only ability levelling being a personal strategy is concerning)- 90% of the community (therefore around 90 players) are still either toxic, or don't speak English so communication here is just the one between labradors and shrimps- no update since summer 2015.... is this con alone enough?- note: Even though no skill is required, since the game isn't being maintained a lot there are some people who don't play without... Inconviniently fair program tools for winning, so don't think you can use this game as an indicator you still know how to play games after you died 1234567898765432345678987654334567 times in Dark souls...Enjoy :)

content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												Anybody who is new to a moba should play this game! Dragons and Titans doesn't feel overwhelming and its has just the right amount of pacing to get into it and have fun. There are no microtransactions for any player to feel frustrated and most of the items such as the runes, rune slots, the weapon packs, and dragon packs, can be purchased through in-game currency. However, the exeptions are that you can't purchase the dragon skins, the avatar riders, also the dragons and weapons individually. You can upgrade your weapons and the dragons you have so you can become stronger, faster and better. Players get to try five weapons and dragons each week as well. There are other ways to get free dragons but purchasing the Titans Pass can save you the hassle by getting all the weapons, all the dragons, the skins, the riders and all of the acts. When you do, the in-game currency gets an extra boost the more you play. Not to mention you recieve the latest weapon or dragon now and then. The Titans Pass only lasts for a year, but don't worry you still get to keep everything else except the currency boost. The only thing I can complain about are the Acts. If you do it for the story and free dragon they're okay but it does get tedious the more you play. I wish the makers of Dragons and Titans would be a little more creative on the gameplay for the acts. But everything else is very much worth it.

content:
Posted: May 8, 2015
												This game is sort of pay to win. There is a rune system like LoL, but each dragon has 4 tiers in which each tier is significantly stronger than dragons of a lower tier. Dragons on the free rotation and dragons you first buy are all tier 1, and you must get tier 1 dragons of the same type to get a tier 2 of that dragon, and there are 4 tiers. Not to mention, you can't buy a single dragon or weapon of your choice with in-game currency, you can only buy packs of 3 random dragons or packs of 3 random weapons. Yes, random, so if you've farmed up the crystals you still won't get that dragon or weapon of your choice. Maps are also rotated on the server (EDIT: since review was written, this was changed to a vote system), so you won't be able to always play your favorite. Everything is done with the excuse of "low playerbase" or something.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2014
												 It's really no strategy involved. Eveyone does the something every game. It's a facebook app so it's more so made for the causual player. The concept of the dragons is the only thing that keeps my interest. A fade for right now. All the so call experts players do is play with their friends or so-call clans, which is basically the best stretagy in this game for winning. TEAM WORK. The rating system is a joke, just based on W/L. Rather than individual achievements. The losing team players may have better stats than the winning team, yet gets no rewards for KDR, structures destroyed, gold collected, minions killed or asssist , Just the L. Meanwhile, the winning team feeder who goes 0-8 and contributed nothing to the W get points, stupid. It's annoying to listen to the so-called expert players and moderators talk about how much strategy it take to win, really when either team can have the same dragons and weapon its no STRATEGY involved other than the team who has BETTER TEAMWORK WINS. Their's no in game gear to buy to adjust your STRATEGY, their's not picking of dragons or weapons to counter the other team STRATEGY. BECAUSE IT DOES NOT EXIST. Hell, you can't even see the other team pick until the game actually start, maybe thats a developer STRATEGY. A poster metioned this game is better than DOTA2, this game is childs play compared to DOTA2, clueless comment. Lets take DOTA2 for example, every charatcter has it's strenght and weakness, you can't play 2 of the same hero on different team .BTW it is the dumdness thing in any MOBA game to have the same charatcter on different teams. You have different roles for each player in DOTA2, support/carry/mid/hard lane/jugler etc. You have real STRATEGY involved, last hitting creeps, pulling creep wave, dening creeps, calling for ganks. You can counter any character with another one, for example Drow ranger or Sniper who are consider OP by noobs can easily be owned by a Huskar or Spring Breaker, Huskar can be handle by a Chos knight. Again picking the right character to counter your opponent, it's called STRATEGY. NONE OF WHICH EXIST IN THIS GAME. Next, it's the most buged game i've ever played always crashing, I tried playing with my game pad EVERY game I lagged out and crashed. All the so-called expert  players speed hack/cheat. Now, the nickel and dime aspect, i will disclaim I have spent more than $130 USD on this game and have played grater than 200 hrs. Everything  is randomized so you grind for 5K crystals and randomized a dragon or weapon you don't want, you can't trade it to another player, NO MONEY INVOLVED IN THAT,  all you can do is sell it for a fraction of what you grind for, basically a waste of your time. Then thiers runes completion which takes UP TO 48hrs to complete, why I have no clue, maybe they are using a sweat shop in China to do the work. Weapon forge can take an eternity,  again maybe this one is sent to India for completion, unless you buy instance item to complete forge, money grab basically. After 200 hrs, I have not randomized any items i want, thus spending my own cash, good marketing strategy. Bottom line, this is a causal game, repetitious game play with no real substance and indepth game play or STREATGY. They just celebrated 300,000 likes on FB, but at peak EST around 8pm thiers only around 500 players on. That in it self tells you everything you need to know about this game. That is all, peace.

												TL:DR: PAY TO WIN, salty community, heavy AFKing in matches, botting in pvp matchesGame has a good idea behind it...but it just doesnt follow thru properly.Games get pretty boring and repetative VERY fast, everyone votes for a map that will be run for the next 30 min by everyone playing, there are 4 maps total...you will only ever play 3 of them as one is consistently voted into oblivion.This might not seem like a pay-2-win game...but it is..it takes a VERY long tim just to buy a dragon pack (requires 5k crystals) and those dragons you get are completely RANDOM..you cant actually just BUY a specific dragon that you want.I tested to see how long it would take to reach 5k crystals i nthe first place (ONLY playing pvp) took roughly 13 HOURS.now that might not seem like much, but considering you dont have a choice in what dragon you get, and in order to upgrade a dragon, you have to have 3 of those dragons PER upgrade...meaning: 3 t1 dragons of the same type for 1 t2 dragon...and then 3 t2 dragons for 1 t3 dragon.this will take a VERY VERY VERY long time..so long that there is basically NO possible way of doing it WITHOUT paying money.There is an english language channel...and no one really speaks any english.People playing games dont speak english and when you say "english?" you usually get cussed out in spanish/portuguese/brazillian........ take your pick.People afk games if they die once, botting is pretty heavy, plenty in those 13 hours of playing.Just all-in-all.....not worth your time.

Posted: October 14, 2014
												 First of all, i don't know if i should be writing this review. You see, i am here for the dragons. And boy there are some. You see, the game does its name justice, and because of that it forced me to be playing frantically a genre i've come to hate and have very few, unpleasant experiences with. The MOBA.  Fortunately, riding a flaming winged terror and hunting down and killing strangers is as rewarding as it sounds. There's more to it though. I mean there's a ton of weapons, a lot of dragons, and you can unlock everything eventually by playing.  I would like to be able to unlock the single player campaign or the avatars but those remain to be seen. There are three arenas to play and those give the old run-and-hunt-and-avoid gameplay some diversity which is always good. The music also sets the mood, but some Rhapsody of fire would go perfectly with it.  To close, i would recomend Dragons and Titans. I would recomend it, because it was all i had hoped it would be and some more, i would recommend it because of dragons, which are always a wonderful theme if used correctly and of the tones of fun i had with it so far.  A last word would go to the pieces of fluff that seem to surround everything. Great job on that, and it really sets the mood.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												Pay to win? More like Play to win!Personally I think Dragons and Titans is a lovely little MOBA. I agree that it can't really compare to games like Dota and League of Legends, but the potential is certainly there.The most common complaints I've seen in reviews are that the game would be Pay to Win and that the controls are clunky. One review even stated you can't attack and fly at the same time.I find these arguments unfounded. All dragons are quite balanced so buying more with money hardly gives you an advantage. The tutorial gives you the crystals(the in game currency) to buy a dragon pack and a weapons pack, both containing 3 random dragons and 3 random weapons respectively. Through playing PVP or the single player campaign you can earn more crystals. I've had pvp games in which I earned about 300 crystals and you need 2500 for a weapons pack and 5000 for a dragons pack.Further more there are a bunch of free to play dragons and weapons to choose from in PVP battles. These dragons and weapons rotate every other week between all the dragons and weapons available.As for the keybinding, I will admit that its hard to get used to at first, but it's hardly clunky. Once you get the feel for it you'll be twisting and turning and breathing whatever your dragons breathing down on your foes. Flying and attacking at the same time is easy to do, some dragons even have homing attacks that will find your target no matter which direction you're facing. There's 3 pvp maps with different game modes and the levels are well designed. Overall the PVP element is the best part of the game as it should be, but the single player campaign is a nice add on.The single player campaign allows you to unlock dragons. Now I've seen a complaint about that in one of the reviews that you would need to clear 150 levels before unlocking the dragon. In truth you only need to play through every level once to unlock the dragon. But I agree that the difficulty is really high even when played in recruit mode. You'll die a lot, get frustrated a lot and if you're anything like me you'll just give up on it and go '♥♥♥♥ it I'm sticking to pvp'But the thing I really like about this game is that you can endlessly combine weapons and dragons. Meaning that you could face off against a dragon with a weapon that shoots arrows one time and then be faced with that same dragon with the ability to drop mines and teleport the next time you face it. It also means that you can choose your own style of play.Further more, the more you play a dragon or weapon, the more experience is awarded to them, allowing them to advance ranks and become faster and more powerfull. So really, the more you play the more powerful your dragons and weapons get and the more likely you are to win!And if that isn't reason enough to give it a try. There's one argument that is sure to at least get me playingIts a Dragon MobA!

content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												Not being a big fan of MOBAs myself, I found this game to be extremely entertaining. I love the take on the genre, and I know others complain about the controls, but frankly, I found them to be a welcome change rather than click click click!Why is this game called Dragons and Titans?You're a dragon lord, who rides dragons into battle. Now, why this is cool is you get a dragon with it's own unique abilities, and your rider can use a helpful weapon, so rather than filling inventory with objects and potions you're using abilities you specify as you progress. Once you reach enemy base, you find YOUR Titan is trapped there, and once you break the cage, you free them.Now for the negatives I noticed.If you are just trying to practice to get a feel for the game, you will want to go and do the prologue and the acts. That's fine and dandy, but the learning curve is harsh even on Easy (because yeah, when I'm new, I'm going to hit Easy, k?) So you will find yourself frustrated time and time again with going through the entire thing after losing 4 lives (4 total, you get 3 hearts, and once you die after that, you have to start over).The biggest, most horrendously awful thing about this game:Sometimes, those acts bug out. Mobs will not come on que as they should to progress, leaving you looking around frustrated until you decide to quit. The good news here is that if you quit "the match" (again, this is an act, not playing with others) you will be able to try it again and then the enemes spawn accordingly. I don't know about you, but that seems almost game breaking to have to QUIT just to play the damn thing. I'm genuinely hoping this is addressed and repaired.Aside from that, I do recommend this game, it's fun, the music is fantastic, and you feel like you're getting somewhere (when things aren't wonky).===Edit===Also, some people are complaining that this is a pay to win game. As of 3/15/2014 this game actually gives you freebies for doing tutorials and stuff. Free crystals to buy a pack of dragons and weapons. No, you can't specify which ones you get, but I'm not complaining x3

number of helpful: 43 of 79 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												The whole MOBA concept as we know it now is highly overrated as it's seriously flawed by a number of issues, such as too long matches, repetitive game play with same builds, and community harassment. I've played DOTA and LOL pretty extensively but eventually left both. As for DaT it has addressed a number of key issues of the concept while adding a nice twist to it. The game plays differently unlike any MOBA you've played before, but the new control system seems to work pretty nice since you cannot lose your character in the middle of the fight, which often happens with inexperienced players in other MOBAs, designers have put a lot of thought and imagination in the dragons and the main map feels better that a regular "three lanes" map. The matches are usually 10-15 minutes long, so even if you're stuck with a bad team, it doesn't hurt you all that much, hence no harassment. The flaw with repetitive builds was fixed with weapons that are chosen before the match: they give you two abilities along with the two provided by your dragon. This gives you an imaginable number of variants that will keep you from getting bored for a long timeAll in all, this game won't replace DOTA2 or LoL but will have a consistent player base that will grow over time. As for those claiming it to be "P2W", those players don't understand the whole concept of this model. DaT is a free to play title since no other player will get an advantage over you that you will not be able to get eventually, it does require some grind, but when you enjoy the game you don't really notice it. The only flaw I've come across - the game needs some polishing, but I believe it will get there eventually.9/10

number of helpful: 43 of 79 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
												This is a great game with a rocky beginning - I highly suggest you get through the tutorial and play at least 2 or 3 of the 5v5 PVP battles before passing judgment.  In addition to the cool lore and novelty of a moba in which you fly on a dragon's back, there are several key features that I think are innovative and make this game different from the rest of the pack:* Pressing spacebar lets you move backwards but still face forward, which makes for some interesting mechanics in outmanuevering your opponents.  Breathing fire on your opponent while backpedaling is also just fun!* The typical 4 abilities of most MOBAs are split - you get 2 from your dragon and 2 from your weapon.  This means you can create a huge number of combinations of abilities, flexibility which is really cool especially once you unlock a lot of dragons and weapons.  In other words, the same dragon can be played in vastly different ways depending on weapon choice.* The matches are typically fast, like 10-20 minutes, which is nice - I don't have to dedicate as much time to drop in and play a game here and there.* There are no in-match items to buy.  I love this becuase I don't have to memorize a huge inventory to play the game (or spend time sitting there agonizing over my item choice).  I can just concentrate on the game itself.* There is much less focus on killing minions, and much more focus on fighting the other players dragons.The art is beautiful but a bit rough around the edges, and the interface is serviceable but could be a bit more intuitive.At its core, Dragons and Titans is a great game that does key things differently from the MOBA crowd.  It fits great for me as a game I can drop in and play here and there without having to read tomes to catch up on what I missed or be screamed at for being a newb every moment when I play again and forget item builds...It may not draw you in with its tutorial, but give it a chance to shine and it does not disappoint.

												The game feels empty, lacking of stuff that makes it feel like you're actually flying mighty dragons, battling other powerful dragons. The movement mechanics are unique, but not any preferable movement system for me. Ontop of that, the game kept bugging out at all different times, and for what I've played, trying to get Crystals (ingame money) is much more tedious than it should be, which doesn't help the already lacking game.Also, as a 2014 game, the graphics and the animations are falling behind, the game has flat textures and the animations feel clunky.

number of helpful: 9 of 14 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2014
												First off, I would like to make it clear that I have also played this game earlier, outside of steam, so my total playtime is probably at around five hours. With that out of the way, this game just is not very good. Its graphics are meh, though they certainly do the job, sound assets are pretty horrid, the voice acting terrible, the controls rather clunky, and the abilities very dull. It also feels very unpolished, with several bugs, a poorly designed UI, and an options menu so poor that it does not even include a sound slider. This, coupled with the terribly loud voices, forced me to take my headphones off while they talked. My overall impression of the game is that of lost potential. It was made to play in a browser, and that is obvious in its design. One could certainly make an argument for it when it was on facebook, as it is of much higher quality then most other games there, but here on steam, well... even the dragons cannot save this one.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2016
												Totally lame.horrible gameplay, with an insanely long begginners guide required before you can play, yet doesn't teach you even half the controls!?? (they can't be found under keybind menu either)Game involves chosing your dragon, and equipping your rider with an offensive and a defensive weapon, then upgrading them.The amount of gems you aquire through quests/dailies etc means it takes about 1 week to upgrade 1 item 1 time...... pay to win incentive is just too strong, with very little benefit from doing so.Player A plays the strongest 'assasin' dragon in the game and has a +3 upgraded weapon and a +1 upgraded dragon, player B plays the weakest 'support' dragon in the game and has a +20 weapon and +17 dragon. Player B will almost 1 shot player A and 5 of his buddies all ganging up on a cornered player B.Do you like to play games which require a $50 investment to begin to compete in casual games (as there is no ladder ranking system currently)? Then this is the game for you! Or for $30 you could just flat out BUY one of the many better alternatives out there.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2016
												Dragons and Titans is a "free to play" MOBA using a dragon theme.  It worked, sounded ok, looked ok, played ok. Has Single player mode, CoOp mode and PVP mode.  Three random dragon pack cost 5,000 crystals and  3 random weapon pack cost 2,500 crystals.  You can earn crystals by playing matches, and you get 1 dragon pack and 1 weapon pack when you finish the Prologue. The tutorial map is a testing range. There are 40ish Dragons to play and 6 are free on rotation.  There are many weapons to use and 6 of them free on rotation.  Only one Map at a time is playable, it is voted on in lobby. There is 5 vs 5 PVP matches.Game looks Pay to Win because you can buy the Dragon and Weapon packs with real money till you get ones you want.  Buying the Titan pass for 20 dollars unlocks all tier 1 Dragons and weapons, single player campaigns and gives 4x crystals earned for one year.Try it, maybe you might like it.  For more info:

												This is an amazing game i dont see myself ever geting board of this game.this game does featureAlmost too many dragons too train them all a great plus that I love so dont think too many is a bad thing.There are a lot of spells that can be used like a spell that restors my mana and another for health some.  Also there is a PvP, Co-Op, and single player modes. Co-Op is the hardest to get into a match but my personle faverate. you have 5 players including you against 5 CPU's. Then there is PvP 5v5 players (The players in PvP tend to be more rude and complain more.) And Finaly we have single player in this mode you can set the game type you like and its you along with a team of 4 CPU's Against a team of 5 CPU's  another reason for some who may enjoy is weapons yes theres weapons for you "Dragon lord" to carry. the weapons have a set of abilitys aswell just as the dragon does wich you unlock those abilitys by gaining XP wich you get from killing damageing dragons or getting gold.  One of the best parts of this game is that its completely free.Also if you thought this reveiw was helpful please put that below.Post Note: (This game aint no minecraft so please dont expect there too be like 367,341,543 players or whatever.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												Game is random? Yes i give it that.Fun? Beyond fun yes!P2w? Not at all, everything you want in this game you can grind for, but of course there is the quick "warrior walleting" out of the grind. The only thing that you can't get in this game through grinding is some skins and avatars that can only be bought with cash. There is nothing you can buy to give you the advantage over other players.So would I recommend you playing the gaming? Do I think its worth the time and effort? Of course, through GRINDING i have gotten every dragon and weapon in game, as for the random, its not too hard to manage, you quickly learn how to use what you have very well.EDIT: I'll leave my original review there for everyone to see, but after some recent events I honestly can't recommend this anymore. I used to love this game with my heart and soul and it was amazing. But then the developers abandoned it, I just can't recommend it anymore. The free rotations haven't changed in months, the seasonal rewards are random t4 dragons, there are constantly people having trouble to connect to this game, there is an insane ammount of unbalanced weapons, dragons and combos in this game. It saddens me to say this but unless the devs come back to this game I recommend everyone stay away from it because you'll only be wasting your time.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2014
												If you like dragons...you MUST at least try this game, no matter if others think is bad, you need to discover it by yourself.This game have too many negative evaluations, I think because maybe one tried it and had a bug (is something that can happen, but with any game) or had not a good impression at first time. And besides any possible reason, if one just do not like a thing or a game, should just move on and go to find a new one, not be so destructive against one, it's unuseful and give just bad repercussions, and there is no needed of that.The game is good and enjoyable, but it need more players! and when people come here to see the reviews and see all this negative votes are are discouraged and do not give it a try even if it's a Free to Play !!The game need more good reviews, I think that ANY player that like Dragons and Titans, should tell others that, and not only in the chat, but write a positive review here and suggest it to other people! And I'm here to do it!There is a part of pay to win too but it's almost insignificant, because if you like the game and enjoy to play as a DRAGON RIDER you'll gain things easy and with time, the beautiful aspect of this game besides the fact that you can chat and play with others, do pvp (players against other players) is that there are many dragons! And you can collect them and try them during the time, same for the weapons! that are many and different, this aspect make the game to have also a strategy side, it's not just about to throw your dragon against the enemy, but you have to learn each ability and potential, and also collaborate with others players and make a plan. You can also play easy against the computer in single player and with others too making co-op The game may seems repetitive or boring, but the fact is that every game have a line, its history and structure, each in its own way it is structured with certain bases, and the rest comes from the actions that one does and how he lives it, as it acts. And this one make no exceptions, and it works following a precise line.Personally I use a lot my imagination too, and I just love to see dragons, to play them and see the animations during the battles!!So let's give it a try!! it deserve it :)and share it Dragons Lords !!!

content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
												This game is a pretty obvious MOBA much like DOTA.  It is not as refined or deep as many other MOBAs but there is a fairly high amount of constant innovation despite the small development team.  Updates including new dragons, maps and other features are quarterly.  There is a fair amount of strategy and required synergy between dragons, weapons, spells and runes per map so while you can learn to play fairly quickly, to play well takes more time.The game isn't perfect but it is fun and the Titan Pass for full content is a pretty good deal.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												Extremely fun MOBA. I refuse to be a wallet warrior and pay to level. D&T has a nice per year subscription model that gives you access to all of the current and future dragons and weapons on first tier for the year. Additionally buying the annual pass will increase your Gem and XP rewards. This game will allow you to play properly for free. There is nothing you can buy that you cannot get for free, however it will take a bit longer without the reward multiplier from the Titan Pass. Very fun and addictive. I would rate this 4 out of 5. The missing star is for a few of the bugs in game, especially the UI which tends to be a bit flaky at times, but otherwise gameplay is excellent.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 20, 2014
												Fundamentally, this game can accurately be described as Hoard + Dota 2. It's pretty fun, in a simplistic sort of way, which I like. And it has good microtransaction policies, which is to say there are none. Which I like. There is only one thing purchasable in this game (aside from the in-game currency), which is a sort of season pass, and, honestly, it's very humbly priced and a good deal ($20 for all the content made thus far, the future content they make for the next year, and 4x money). If you like the game, buying that is definitely worth considering, and it's still not pay to win, for the developers seem adamantly against that sort of thing.There is a good variety of dragons too, and it doesn't overwhelm you with the sheer amount like Dota 2 does. In this game, you play as the dragons (well, a guy riding them) and must protect the titans for the fate of the world. A lot more clear-cut than whatever story Dota 2 happens to have. Like, why the ♥♥♥♥ is a building called an ancient? An ancient is a really old living being, and those "ancients" are not living beings from what I can tell. They are buildings. And that word is mostly an adjective. Mostly. And on that note, there is a dragon that looks like a xenomorph!But anyway, it could use some extra polish with the UI presentation, but it's not unsightly. Matches are quite short, which you may or may not like, but I think it is a good thing, personally. You can also really customize your abilities and strategy, since your choice of dragon nets you two abilities, and your choice of weapon nets you two different abilities. So you can mix and match. It also has a good tutorial, so I'd definitely say this a good introduction to the MOBA genre.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2014
												Pros: Takes MOBA concepts and puts them on the backs of dragons, which is never a bad thing. Dragon, weapon and spell combinations offer plenty of play style options. Solo and co-op play as well as ranked battles.Cons: Rune system leaves a little too much to chance. Forces some social game aspects into the mix with Battle Marks. Only one map.I have mixed feelings about this game. However, I do recommend to try it out. It's free after all.

number of helpful: 22 of 43 people (51%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25, 2014
												Fun little moba, while most have you wait and bide your time, This one throws you head first into the action and matches quickly start out with a massive team fight. Games usually take between 10-20 minutes so its easy to do a few matches. As for shop items, Dragons and weapons are easily buyable with ingame money (Crystals) which are not to hard to farm up, or real money for a quick boost. Dragons come in packs of 3 random ones, but you can buy specific ones for real money. Vanity items such as skins and avatars are bought with real money.Apon starting a game you will choose one dragon and one weapon, all dragons have a general boost to character health and mana, as well as gold collection. Your dragon selection will modify your first 2 abilities as well as general stats such as speed, attack power, as well as attacks. The weapon you choose provides your last 2 attacks and each weapon is highly varied in which attacks it offers as well as utilities. Some weapon offer additional attacks, while others are passive buffs and still others boost in movement.  You also have 2 spells avalible to use.Dragons and Titans offers several game modes including a single player adventure mode which allows you to earn special rewards. All of the Pvp game modes involve freeing your titan from the enemies, but each mode involves somewhat different methods to go through. Gold is avalible to collect and return in all game modes. Gold offers experience as well as in some game modes provides additional benefits.Moba involves traveling through a wide and open map with various areas to explore. Unlike standard mobas this one does not have specific lanes, or a "Jungle" to explore. Collecting gold here and returning it to the hoards here will summon a chaos titan who is a powerful boss creature that heals allies and shreds towers. Aid your titan to help it push to the heart of your enemies base. Apon summoning a titan, all progress towards your enemies titan is lost so gather gold often to ensure you're the one with the advantage.Control points has 5 control points that when captured slowly weaken the enemies titan cage shields. Gold here just offers experience and no added benefits. Once a control point is captured, you can teleport to it from the hoard as well as function as a gold drop off. Aram is an all random mode that is just one quick fast paced lane where all dragons are randomly selected for the user while weapons can still be chosen freely. Gold is automatically dropped off and when the bar fills fully it will fire a set of 3 balistae to deal massive damage to anything in the path, This damage is enough to oneshot most dragons. Over all Dragons and titans is a nice fast paced moba that is still in active development. It stands differently to League of Legends as well as Dota 2, and I highly recommend it as a way to get people into mobas in general.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												I have to say that this game is fairly good. Though I only have a few hours of gameplay to boast, I still think that I know enough to say that this game is worth your time. The system of dragon/weapon is easy to understand, the movement is simple, the matches are complex enough to be interesting but not complex to the point of overwhelming, and the act system offers more challenges than you normally find in an MOBA, along with the Titan Pass which offers you a complete collection of every item in the game for the low, low price of $19.99 (or $9.99 if you're getting it on a sale as I did.) To top it all off, the download is only a bit over 100MB.The only issues I really have with the game are that it's a bit grindier if you don't get the Titan Pass, and- mentioning the TP again- it seems that you are unable to play the acts beyond Act 1 without unlocking them with the TP. It's not much of an issue though, because the TP is only $19.99 and it's only necessary to purchase it once- no subscriptions and no extra DLC packages.

												The game itself is very well made, and all of it feels smooth and works well; however the only concern i have is how the single player campaign is set out and that you need certain dragons to proceed and get the ultimate prize from the single-player campaign, however this is talking about the BEST reward from it, so grind will be required but it isn't that bad.In terms of the PvP: the servers are a little bit jumpy in places but overall it is very stable and I have enjoyed playing it ever once in a while; so playing it constantly can feel a bit dull without access to everything, but working towards your next dragons is a great feeling.The currency is fair as it gives a fair amount per game and you get 3 dragons for the amount of 5000 gems; the only complaint I have about the currency is that you can't buy individual dragons without paying in real money and this is a handicap I feel, as you can't really get what you want when you want.Overall the game is good but it will take some time to get into, besides that it is a great game.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2014
												I wouldn't say this is pay to win, but it's definitely pay to get what you actually want.You can purchase what you "need" with in game money but what you get is random; so if you wanted that shiny gold dragon on the list you either buy it with irl money or keep buying random ones with in-game money, which you won't want to do. Each random "pack" of dragons (which is only three may I add) costs 5000 in-game money and you need more than one to get the highest teir dragon... Storyline missions and battles only give you around 20-60 each. Don't think you can complete tutorial objectives to speed this up as you start out either, how about a 50 reward for a task that requires you spend 150.So you either want to pay or you're in for the hard slog for that shiny gold dragon you set your eyes on.This game also doesn't have much to do when it comes to the matches in multiplayer and from what I've seen there is only one map per game-mode, making it rather boring after a while. The tutorial is lacking... the options are even more lacking... i.e. prety much non-existent, and I can see why it makes some people think facebook game... I also came to the realization that this game isn't technically free to play at all and that's a misleading claim to draw you in. The DLC for this is literally the game and theres only two parts of DLC so far, which may I just say you will not want. Each DLC gives you 10 relatively short missions and you have to complete each mission 15 times over with different requirements to unlock the best prize. That isn't replayability, it's just a SLOG. No prize is worth the aggrevation of dragging yourself through the same 10 scenarios 15 times over! So this game is not only mingy, but misleading, very short on content and is money-intensive.I'm still playing it, but it's not getting a thumbs up from me.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2014
												I have played this game for 42 hours on this acount (plus some more an my friends account) and i honestly dont see why it is getting so many bad reviews. I see some things that could be fixed, but not much.First of all, a lot of people are having problems with the compaign as in finding it too hard to complete or the time you have to put into it just to get a new dragon. i'm just going to mention that the dragons in it are not the best ones to have anyway. so i went through all the act 1 campaign missions with only having to restart once in recruit, and it was the last mission. you have 3 respawns before you die and it isn't too hard to complete. Yes its a bit difficult to be at recruit level, but i still managed to do it fairly easily. One thing that does annoy me is that after the first act is complete, you have to buy the second act onwards. now this promoted the game as a pay to win, and i know that people wanting single player aspects of the game will be unhappy about this, buy there is still a 5v5 single player match ♥♥♥♥hting with bots that can give you crystals.Secondly, they try to get you to pay for the dragons and weapons, but it really isn't needed. You get about 70 crystals per match (+ about 50-100 if you complete the mission that is given to you). this deosnt seem like a lot as the weapons pack costs 5000 and weapon packs cost 2500 crystals, but most matches you play pass really fast, and you will be surprised how fast the crystals stack up if you just play a few matches at a time.Another thing people are saying about this game is that the contols are clucky. me and my friends found them pretty easy to get used to, and i see new players not having much trouble moving around and fighting at the same time. its oretty easy to understand, right click somewhere to move to that location, letf click for your 1st attacka dn W, E and R for your other attacks. these are the basic controls that will be pretty much all you need to play in a match.The totorial is fairly okay, but you can get lost easily and they dont explain some things very clearly. This is pretty much my only problem with the game in my oppinion. Even if it's not your kind of game, it's free so i'd give it a try :3

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
												Want to play a MOBA without microtransactions? Titans pass gives you x4 gems which is the currency used to buy dragon eggs and weapon packs. Dragon egg packs cost 5000 gems  and weapon packs cost 2500 gems. Gems are earned by playing matches and is the only currency in game. Titans pass gives you all the dragons and weapons available. So you don't need to buy weapon. But that dosn't mean you need to stop buying  dragon packs. Because in this game. There are ways of making your favored combo stronger. BUT this involved getting to know every dragon. So dragon packs are the only way to do this. You combine 3 of the same dragons to increase its teir. A higher teired dragon has more health and reduced cooldown for abilities. There is also more health regen. Likewise. Weapons themselves can be paired with any dragon. Allowing versitility of the play style of over 27 dragons and weapons to make combinations with, and a growing list of weapons and dragons monthly. Titans pass gives you all the content you would get from microtransactions for a solid year. So any dragon or weapon to be released is yours. But as mentioned. Your farming quest is not over when you buy Titans pass. Because you still need to farm Mastery, another way to maximize your dragon. By playing your dragon more, the dragon itself gains xp going up in mastery rank with 5 teirs. First teir is basic, Second teir is bronze theird is silver fourth is gold and 5th is platnium. With each mastery upgrade to your favored dragon it gains more health and becomes faster and stronger. But don't let that fool you into thinking its an automatic win. Because combos and team mate support is the basic structure of this game. With good combos, and good team support. You have a better chance of winning. And with titan pass. You get to start with your favored combos early. And believe me there are over 70 combos currently to chose from. How? Because of runes and weapons forge. That is why. Not only do weapons have their own play style coupled with dragons. But there are 30 ranks which you the player earn. You buy runes packs of 3 to give your dragon those extra stats you need to make your combo you want TO WORK. THAT'S RIGHT. 2 runes activate every time you level. So you need to pick wisely what your combo will be. Survivability? Damage? Support? Tank? What will you play? There is so much to chose from. In any other MOBA you would have to shell out hundreds of dollars to get the oppertunity you get here for 20$. And even if you don't pay. You could easily achieve such status in a month of playtime. They give you 3 dragons every 15 days as long as you log in everyday and claim the daily reward. 1 basic dragon one t2 and on the 15th day a random t3. It's insainity what happens during the games now. With people shelling out their best combos games get hectic. WHen you think you can charge in solo is usually the time you should backup cuz flames and bolts are flying all over the place. Learning manuverability is extremely important in this game. and besides all those nice things. Skins. Yes skins. and avatars. If you buy titan pass you get any skin and avatar made for the next year. Best of all you get to keep everything you earn in this game, or buy with titan pass. You keep all the dragons weapons except the gem bonus for a year. You would need to buy titan pass again after the year is over. And a year LOL come on.... 12 months for 20 bucks for crap that would cost you hundreds ( Who in their right mind would pay that much for any microtransactions on a moba?!?) This game isn't trying to rob you folks. This is probably the only customer friendly moba out there, They literally catter to our whims in forums. So we could use more devs to catter to our whims if you decide to buy this thing. I wrote this review because the people who rip on this game are savage at filling the steam reviews with garbage.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2014
												Russian and EnglishЯ лично не люблю free-to-play - опыт показывает что когда игра "надоит" денег разработчики просто продадут её кому-нибудь  или перекроят так что играть без доната будет невозможно - но пока в эту игру можно играть, надеюсь так и останется. Я оказался прав. Баланс игры не был даже поправлен, и вряд ли будет - разработчики теперь просто "пихают" туда мини-аддоны (+1 оружие, дракон и т.п.) и всё. Ждите перепродажи игры с её полной перекройкой.Первые ласточки - теперь уже невозможно выбрать карту для сражения. Но хоть НАКОНЕЦ-ТО добавили античиты и чуть убрали доминацию тач-падов.Итак игра формата Доты на драконах - правда с несколькими плюсами: - поправляю - теперь эти плюсы работают только для ко-оп мачта1) Намного быстрее - матч не больше 15 минут2) При использовании дракона и оружия мастерство растёт - но опыт оружия ничего не даёт, а вот здоровье и скорость дракона растёт.3) Вы всегда получите 2 ед. ресурса за игру для прокачки (ковки) оружия - если соберете их (используйте радар)4) Постоянные мини-достижения за которые вы премируетесь небольшой суммой кристаллов - сыграть 3 раза подряд в мачт (неважно в одиночной или мульти) к примеруВердикт - надеюсь игра останется на этом уровне "бесплатности", но жадность людей штука коварная...Имеет смысл если вы очень любите коллекционировать - дракончики бесподобны. I, hypostasial, dislike games free-to-play - experience shows that when game earn "a lot of money" delopers often selling it as franchise or will make gameplay impossible without donates - but this day this game can be played with no donate.Balance even wasn't "attempted to be fixed" and i had a big doubt that it will be - now developers just add "new content" (+1 weapon, dragon e.t.c.). Will wait for franchise soon with full change of game model i think.Now you can't pick game map. However they AT LAST added anti-cheats and fixed touch-pad superiority.So,.. we have a Dota-style on dragons - but with few features: - fixing - now it's all working for co-op only1) Fast - match no more 15 minutes2) Mastery of weapons and dragon will increase with every game - no boosts for weapon, but dragon get more health and speed3) You always get 2 points of resourse that needed to forge weapon - if you manage to collect it on map (use radar map)4) Permanently repeated mini-in-game achievments that give you a bonus small pack of crystals - like to complete 3 matches and no matter in single- or multi-modeVerdict - I hope that this game will continiue that type of "free", but human's greed is very treacherous vice...This game will be interest if you like collecteables - dragons are unmatched in that.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2014
												MOBA based on dragons, weapons and elements.Choose to either play the campaign or jump into games VS real people or bots. You pick a dragon of your choice, being different from each other and depending on its element, will give you two unique abilities - Q and R. Q is your main attack, it cost little mana and normally has a small cooldown, W is your secondary attack, usually if your dragon has an escape or damage reduction ability, its situated here. Now for the weapon, you get to pick an item of your choice to wield into battle, giving you the other two abilities, your E and R. Depending on what type of build you wish to play, these items will give different skills. Example is a mace that gives massive mana regen as a passive, your E, while the R is a dmg ability. Some items are strickly support, some are healing, some are damage and some are a mix of both. This allows you to play the same dragon with different weapons to create completely new builds and playstyles.There are no items in this game, the gold you collect from killing enemy players and minions is stored on your person and requires you to return back to base and dump the gold in a pile. This then gives you experience depending on how much gold you had stored away.Three different gamemodes, ARAM, normal MOBA with three lanes and a zone capture gametype.You begin the game with 3 random dragons and 3 random weapons, so if you don't get what you want, you will need to play a bunch of games for crystals to buy the desired items or pay real money for bundles.The objective of both the ARAM and normal 3 lane MOBA is to destroy the turrets linked to a statue, then destroy the statue to deactivate a forcefield that weakens your dragon and slows down his speed. Do this several times until you reach your titan and release it from its prison, (attack the main objective, like the nexus in LoL) and the game is over.I play League of Legends a lot of the time, so that satiates all my MOBA needs, but I do recommend trying it out, its free and pretty fun if your willing to get the hang of it.Personal Rating: 3/5

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												The patch of 01/04/2014 which introduced an auto-aim really did dumb down the key strategic aspect of the game and  in my opinion this was one of the stronger points of the game. It no longer requires any skill at all to play which is painfully obvious after playing one match after another with 1-3 of your 4 teammates where always going afk, and pulling out a win albeit unlikely is still possible. By reducing the competitiveness of PvP to the extreme that they have, and not only with auto-aim but with matchmaking as well they made this feel like a "grade school level" type of moba where even basic levels of tactics, strategy, and intelligence are obsolete as Teamplay and individual skills no longer exists. The developers of this game boasts that this is a fast pace game and in fact it once was, today however the number of users using 1 hit kill hacks or speedhacks has made the community who do still play legit feel unmotivated during gameplay which is likely why there are now so many afkers on both sides in every match. While this can still be a fun game to play especially when both team are actually competing at their best, this however is becoming a rare sight. To give you some prospective, out of 30 matches I played today only 6 of them where interesting or engaging battles with all 10 players participating the others where mediocre 1 sided bouts often lasting under 60 seconds due to large amounts of afk'ing going on right from the start of the match, and at lest 4 of them had 1 or more hackers in it.In short the game itself is very fun and recommended,  it's the community's lack of interest or motivation to participate in the matches they chose to join that is in my opinion dragging this game down. And I believe that is ultimately cause by a horrible lack of competitiveness that the developers have now brought to the game.With that said I wouldn't recommend this game to all the competitive players of a moba genre, though I would recommend it to the more casual players,  first timers, and  perhaps the younger crowd of players just looking for a good time

												among many moba games i played, i can say i like this one more than most.the controls feel more "action" based than the rapid clicking of the right mouse button ou're pprobably used to in a moba. a refreshing change.the skills setup for each "hero" is left up to the player:a dragon gets their own 2 skills(one your basic attack, triggered with the left mouse button, and the other a skill usually exclusive to that dragon). it also gets 2 additional skills from a weapon you have chosen(among the free rotation weapons and what you already own), allowing a healer to set mines or cannons and a close ranged nuker to assassinate from long range.i cant cover everything but i will say this: rather than the pay to win people in the review section say this is, the experienced(or atleast the guy who played this game longer) will have an advantage, unless the person who pays really opens up their wallet to forge his weapon to the max right from the start and instantly jumps to a fully upgraded dragon(and even so the advantage is small enough to allow everyone a chance at winning)

content:
Posted: April 7, 2014
												Ok, first I have to say, I am a pro at this game. I am level 27 and have 86 in game hours. That said this is a very unique game.It is very well balanced. It's never happens that some rich kid that spent a ton of money in game comes up with some superweapon and annihilates everyone. The games are rank based so if your a lvl 2 noob the youll play level 1-5 players  who are also noobs. The number of weapon - dragon combinations are staggering. with over 30 wepons and 30 dragons that can be combined in any way you have millons of combinatons. And the viarances on the playing style on each is so different you will never exaust   the posibilites. And the balance between the different weapon am dragon types is amazing.If you were expecting graphics likw in a multimilon dollar game like bioshock, well, you'll be dissapointed of course. This game is free. No money needed. In fact, paying money in game only gives you different options. It doesn't give you more powerfull options. Paying money makes absoultely no difference in pvp games. As far as as free to play goes, this game is excelent. Allowing players to spend money without unbalancing the pvp games.If you want a free to play moba, this is it.
