content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												wow so many negative reviews about things that are totally pointless."hurrdurr its pay2win""its clunky controls""the tutorial is crap"no, and no.This is a MOBA. The tutorial takes about 20 minutes, this gets you enough ingame currency to buy 3 random dragons and 3 random weapons. Each dragon has 2 abilities, and each weapon has 2 abilities, you can use any weapon with any dragon. You also get 2 spells to use on long cooldowns.With the standard controls you hold Right click to move, and leftclick to attack with your primary ability. You can use Q W for your dragon abilities, E R for your weapon, and D F for your extra spells.If you pay, you can get things earlier than others, stronger dragons, upgrades, etc, but you can earn these through playtime anyway. The only thing that is pay2win is potions, that are only available for the single player campaign anyway.

												Awesome dragon fights, and 30 or so cool dragons got me to download this game.Pros:~Has several game modes. I always like a game that lets you have a free play mode, multiplayer mode, or a Story line.~Cool dragons, each with it's own legend.~Tips for each dragon, which make it easier to fight if you take the time to read them.~Cool weapons to go with the dragons, also with they're own legends.~Challenging gameplay across all modes, but it's still not hard to complete~In game purchases. Most of which are not nessesary, but they give you a boost.Cons:~The map for forging weapons is a little to extensive and it costs an unreasonable amount of materials to upgrade anything. It also takes forever to find the resources in game, so you may have to buy them.~It takes forever just to get enough gems to get any new weapons or dragons ~You absolutly HAVE to buy new avatars with real money, not gems. And one thing I found particularly funny is one of the weapons:Unity Mark: The Engine of MagicThe pros definently out weigh the cons, and this game makes a great MMORPG or just an RPG if you don't want to play PvP or Co-op.EDIT: I just found out its called a MOBA. *Has major DUH! moment*

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 31, 2014
												I loved the game at first, but the more I play it the more it irritates me.  At the lower levels, you can spend a few hours here and there having a blast, learning how to play and what dragon and weapon combination you can do the most damage with.  Unfortunately, leveling up too soon slows to a near halt, and you begin to realize just how unbalanced some of the types of attacks are.  An "update" early in 2014 added an auto-lock aim and the ability to strafe.  Add that to certain overly powerful attacks from certain dragons and you have inescapable death.  Seriously.  That's not an exaggeration.  It's impossible to avoid the attacks.  This kills the fun and often causes me to rage quit.  However, all that aside, I always end up going back to the game and trying again, with the (possibly foolish) hope that at some point perhaps I'll figure out how to defeat this foe, or the more likely hope that I'll get to play a few matches in which those particular attacks don't appear before I face them, die, and repeat the process.Recommend w/ caveat:  If the devs fix the balance issues, I would absolutely, enthusiastically recommend this game.  As is, I recommend it only if you want to spend the money to buy the over-powerful dragons so that you can have the cheap thrill of hollow victories.  Or if you actually don't mind the occasional futile death match.

												Dragons and Titans is a moba style game that feels like a very simple version of League of legends. Though this game is by no means boring to play. The effort put into getting stronger weapons and dragons is lost since this is now literally pay to win. it was better when you were actually better because you worked hard for it. I dont recommend this game to anyone anymore, unless they change it back to be a hard grind for power.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 3, 2015
												Quite a few people mention things such as high level players picking you off in pvp at the early stages, however that's just not true. You can literally pick up the game, start playing and be competitive from the first match till your last - here is why.You start with 3 random dragons which may or may not be high level dragons (each dragon has 4 levels, and with each level you get stat increases such as higher speed or lower mana consumption).Like with most MOBA's, you start each match with just the basic attack unlocked, and as you harvest minions / gold you earn EXP, and when you lvl up you gain an experience point which you use to lvl up current abilities or unlock new ones. You have 4 abilities in total, and two spells which you may change before each match. As you lvl up, you unlock more spells - so yes, higher level players do have access to more spells, but that just makes sense - if it wasn't that way, what would be the incentive to lvl up in the first place?Now - when you join a pvp match EVERYONE starts with the basic abilities of their chosen dragons. Yes, those that have played with a specific dragon for a long while will have mastered his dragon (bronze, silver, gold and I think platinum), and they will receive health and speed bonusses for each lvl), however this rarely causes you to be outmatched in a way that is unforgivable.I just started a new game, and from the first match I played till now I have ALWAYS been competitive. In most matches I can easily obtain a highest score with dragons I haven't even mastered yet - and that's while playing against those that have. So it's just utter garbage that you're cannon fodder for experienced players.Sure, if you're in an inexperienced group you might get wasted every now and again by a better team, but that's just logical, and not due to an unfair advantage.I agree that we need more maps. More maps would make the game feel less repetitive. And perhaps even a few additional game modes (dungeons / raids perhaps?). Oh, and there are not enough support type dragons in my opinion that specializes in buffing / debuffing other dragons. I mean, they have 2 healing dragons, and then one that heals and steals mana, but not in such a way to be a healer - more of a support healer. So perhaps a few more dragons that offer support for their team members rather than just focussing on attack.We also need more players - I think new blood is always good for a game.So in short - I'm enjoying the game and find most pvp matches challenging (other than Ballista Alley which is usually over in just a few minutes).Give the game a try.1. It's free2. Good selection of Dragons (other than support dragons)3. Nice dragon designs and decent graphics4. Fun to play5. Did I say it's free?

content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
												Not quite sure why ppl are giving bad reviews... When I first starting playing I found it annoying that I was always playing against Tier 3  players w/ Platinum weapons/dragons.. so that's why I recommend the Elite Starter Pack, that way you get 7 dragon/weapon packs. Then you have more options when playing the campaign aswell.  On a side note, I finished Act 4 and didn't get a Autodrake...so hopefully when i go thru the harder difficulties i'll get the tier 2 & 3 dragons.Found it kinda interesting that they have you take 3 tier 1 dragons to make a tier 2 dragon, and again 3 tier 2 dragons to get a tier 3. So it takes 9 dragons of the same type to get one tier 3. I seem to be able to buy a 3-pack of dragon eggs almost every week as long as you use the Epic war marks on your First win of the day match to get the most bang for your buck. The trick to farming Crystals is paying attn. to the current Quest and switching between PvP and Single-player modes to grind the quest out... (This was easier before the new random map queue system) Hate when the Collossus gets stuck on the MOBA map.Once a few more bugs are fixed and some more DLC comes out I think this game will be great! I'm just sayin that cuz i <3 dragons and need a break from LoL every once in a while..

Servers are quite frail and random DCs occur now and then.I think the game would be better if one could arrange a party of 5 people instead of just 1 friend at the same time. So much wasted potential but still fun to burn the dead hours.

												Dragons and Titans is a moba style game that feels like a very simple version of League of legends. Though this game is by no means boring to play. The is a great satisfaction from gaining new dragons and weapons while also trying to increase mastery of each dragon and weapon. This game offers single player, co-op, and PvP for all player to play as they wish but the best fun is PvP obviously. Everything cn be purchased with real money so all those hours i spent plaing to forge my weapons 100% is now meaningless. buying dragons and getting random ones doesnt matter since any one can now have a high chance of winning. The effort put into getting stronger weapons and dragons is lost since this is now literally pay to win. it was better when you were actually better because you worked hard for it. I dont recommend this game to anyone anymore, unless they change it back to be a hard grind for power.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												(The following review contains strong language. Hussa for steam censor.)Yeah this may be an unorthadox review, but i decided to go for it. Here´s the review of the ACTUAL game:(07/10) - GoodThe game is fun. There is a ton of content and while you can´t really purchase items ingame, you still have them, granting thousands of possible dragon-weapon combinations. The leveling is also fun, tho it may take a crap load of time... like so much in this game.If you are sick of other people, check out the singleplayer campain, it´s really good as well.That was the review. The problem is, i can´t let that stand. There is just soooooo much wrong with this game, it´s just unbelievable and completly ruins this i-could-have-been-super-fun-to-play game. For each of the following points, i will subtact one from the score, thats how utterly horrible they make the game. And don´t get me wrong, there is tons of♥♥♥♥♥♥wrong, but these are just the biggest porblems:- Unbalanced. What the serious ♥♥♥♥? There is no ♥♥♥♥ing match, which is fair. The developer somehow has no clue on what they are doing and need soo much time to patch let´s say an op dragon, that i´m seriously asking myself what the ♥♥♥♥ they are doing all day long. When i got that dragon as an enemy in a game, i already knew i will loose it. THATS how you destroy fun in matchmaking. And then the patch finally comes (after a ♥♥♥♥ing month!!!) and overpoweres another dragon/item... wtf?Minus one point for unreliable, overpowered crap...- Cheaters. They exist, sure, but does anyone do anything against them? Nope! Cmon man. There is a top ranked player where every ♥♥♥♥ing body knows he´s a cheater, and noone gives a ♥♥♥♥. When you got a cheater in a game, well, fat chance, it´s ruined. And when that happens in a game where no OP♥♥♥♥♥♥was present, ohhh the rage. Yeah... minus one point, for completly ignoring important stuff.- Hitboxes. Ok, here we go: Hoooolyyyy ♥♥♥♥balls!!!!!! If i could, i would ♥♥♥♥ing give 2 minuspoints. THAT ♥♥♥♥ING BAD. Jesus. There is litterly more where the hitbox is wrong, than stuff where it´s right. Heck, even the ♥♥♥♥ing menu buttons are a bit off. And you cant even play some dragons, as their hitbox does not in any way correspond to their attacks. Seriously, i threw one dragon away after 3 matches as i couldn´t hit♥♥♥♥♥♥while hitting hit. Unbelievably horrible! Minus one point, for not being two...- Randomness. There is a ♥♥♥♥ing reason why you can´t program something truly random. Because it has nothing to do in a ♥♥♥♥ing videogame! In none! Unless you got a roulette simulator, get that♥♥♥♥♥♥off your game! I said it for hearthstone, i say it here too, get that in your head defs. "5% to fear each attack" what the ♥♥♥♥? so with luck you completly♥♥♥♥♥♥someone? Yaaay, that must be suuper fun... Let´s spin the wheel: Oh, you hit the 1% box: Minus one point, i´m sorry...- All that other stuff. Yeah, ima just sum them up as a minus one. I mean come on, the game does ♥♥♥♥ing NOTHING for 25 seconds when you click on "exit game". 25 ♥♥♥♥ing seconds!! Then there are unlocks which you will never get in your lifetime. One ♥♥♥♥ing lv 3 rune takes 5 days to craft. ONE ♥♥♥♥ING RUNE. Are you ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ me? And yeah, overall design, response, controls (!!!) and presentation is just bad. Minus one point, for aaaall those little things that just make the experienece worse and inevitable dragging the whole thing down.So here is the actual review for this game:(2/10) - Just BadThe game is good while being horrible. Wait till it get´s patched (a lot, considering the dev actually get´s a tip on what to do) and then play it. Saw me rage there? Thats what the game will do to you if you play it in this state...

content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												Kind of a good game actually. I played it first on browser, then I downloaded it on steam.Pros :+ Wide choice of dragons, they keep updating the dragons+ Amazing dragon design with some additional skins for several dragons+ Each dragon is very different from the others+ Each dragon can be paired with one weapon, which adds two skills to the dragon's skillset+ Great variation of weapons+ Good use of roles, with combinations of dragons and weapons you can make almost any role+ Each weapons and dragons can be upgraded, which is really cool+ Each weapons and dragons can get higher mastery, increasing in-game status+ Good variation of game modes, I'm hoping them to add more though.+ Campaign mode will let you unlock dragons+ Rune system that lets you modify in-game status by applying runes+ You are allowed to use a few selected dragons and weapons you may not own, these selections will be randomized each weekCons :- You get to recieve 3 starting dragons and 3 starting weapon, to unlock more dragons it's pretty expensive. New players may not be encouraged by this- You may buy dragon eggs, but those aren't worth it, they're just too expensive for 3 random dragons- If you want one non-random dragon egg, it's still not worth your money.- Level 15 cap in game is just too shallow- Subscription system! Blergh!- Oh and there is one Cthulhu overpowered dragon and it aint fun- Missions reward you so little- Missions are repetitive and not interesting- Ofcourse you can unlock a dragon from campaign mode, but it takes you 15 levels for one dragon. And mostly it will be a crappy one- Bots are sometimes just too soft- The control is total crap- Auto aims may seem nice from the outside, but it really isn't. It's really annoying- This game is just too greedy- No item system in a MOBA. That's not simple, that just shallow- Your dragon rider looks like an old perverted dude. And you're stuck with it for a long timeI'm not actually pro for this game, but it's still kinda potent. This game may make iti big, but the greedy developers may not agree. I'm 51-49 Pro-Con for this game.

												Initially i thought this game was pretty cool. Giant titans and dragons everywhere. But once you play it, the game is not so satisfying. The PvP matchmaking makes no sense, since you can be matched with players far beyond or below your level, that is just unfair to me, since in this game the longer you play, the stronger you get (as most games thought). The target system is what made my blood boil the most: i can't find out how to switch target at will, being stuck with the "stop attacking to change target" strategy. I also did not like so much the gamemode choice : if you want to play PvP in an unpopular map, you'll have to wait eons for the whole community to pick it, since you can't even choose it at your will.If you want to play a specific map that is not currently being used by the community, you have to play single player, which means just you and AI.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												This would be a fun game if it weren't for the abysmal controls. The camera is locked to your dragon, and rather than having either forward/backward/strafe + mouse aimed abilities or having your dragon move in the direction pressed turning automatically, you have this strange conflicting setup. You can right click to move your dragon, but you also need to use the mouse to aim. Dragons apparently have no necks and can only fire abilities straight forward. There is no strafe key, you can only use the keyboard to move forward, backward or turn, which makes piloting difficult since you have to fight the auto aim/orientation when near an enemy. The only way to strafe is by holding down right click, but that renders you unable to aim at specific enemies.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												This game play's well for it's specific genre. It's a decent piece on it's own, however, the community that is normally playing is less than 200 players according to the game itself. If that isn't the case, then that's just how big individual servers are. When playing single player, the game does freeze up. I'm using a high quality computer, and have the game on low settings, and still have issues with freezing. Multiplayer is definitely fun though, but communication is definitely in need of a few updates. Related to: You can see what everyone on the server is saying, IN GAME. and you can type to everyone on the server IN GAME. It's much more confusing this way, instead of having comms for in a game, and comms for outside a game. The hud would be nice to see some updates, but it's still well rounded. Lastly, paying for campaign is a rather big turn off. I get that the game needs to have an income, but, the first act was annoying as it was, paying for something thats going to be equally annoying, isn't on my bucket list. Maybe make it an unlock from doing certain things like achievements, ect. Make people want to play it more, before paying more. That concludes my review of the game, I do recommend this game with a 3.5/5 stars

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 17, 2015
												While I don't regularly play this game as much as I did before, I still enjoy Dragons and Titans. Its gameplay is simplistic, and pretty much everything is well-designed, both in mechanics and art/figures. If you are feeling bored and trigger-happy, then this game might be good for you.However, the gameplay doesn't involve much strategy. When you pick a game mode you just do a specific attack/defense pattern, and hope for the best. Secondly, the matchmaking system can be a nightmare very often. It just picks five random players for a team, so you frequently see copies of dragons on the same team. Or another case is when the opposing team has several powerful dragons, then your team is screwed. Thirdly, too many of the features require actual cash to be unlocked, like Acts and specific dragons or weapons.Overall, this is a nice game, but it's not worth investing a lot of money in it. Dragons and Titans is only a casual game, albeit a beautiful one.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 31, 2014
												I loved the game at first, but the more I play it the more it irritates me.  At the lower levels, you can spend a few hours here and there having a blast, learning how to play and what dragon and weapon combination you can do the most damage with.  Unfortunately, leveling up too soon slows to a near halt, and you begin to realize just how unbalanced some of the types of attacks are.  An "update" early in 2014 added an auto-lock aim and the ability to strafe.  Add that to certain overly powerful attacks from certain dragons and you have inescapable death.  Seriously.  That's not an exaggeration.  It's impossible to avoid the attacks.  This kills the fun and often causes me to rage quit.  However, all that aside, I always end up going back to the game and trying again, with the (possibly foolish) hope that at some point perhaps I'll figure out how to defeat this foe, or the more likely hope that I'll get to play a few matches in which those particular attacks don't appear before I face them, die, and repeat the process.Recommend w/ caveat:  If the devs fix the balance issues, I would absolutely, enthusiastically recommend this game.  As is, I recommend it only if you want to spend the money to buy the over-powerful dragons so that you can have the cheap thrill of hollow victories.  Or if you actually don't mind the occasional futile death match.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												Curretly I do kind of like this game, but it has a huge amout of problems, specifically to do with the balenceing.Now the game and each of its' maps are and always has been ruled by a select few dragon and weapon combinations that have the highest DPS and pretty much beat any other dragon/weapon in the game, as you can no doubt guess, this plays hell with the game balence, as if you meet one of these wonder combinations on a map it's suited to, then you've pretty much lost before the battle's begun. Wait you cry, what about support and other roles? I'm sorry to dissapoint you, but appart from 1 or 2 healing dragons and weapons which are hardly ever picked anyway, this game is deicded purely on who can dish out the most damage in the shortest amount of time, there's hardy any skill involved when facing an opposing dragon, just simply who is the highest level and who has the highest DPS build.Now the matchmaker, if you could call it that, is also unbalenced. Unlike in most other MOBA's, there's no pregame lobby where everyone selects their dragon and weapon, no, instead you select the dragon, weapon and spells [pretty much the only spells anyone uses are the healing spell and the base teleport] you want before you jump into the game and the matchmaker throws a bunch of random people together, which combined with the fact that there can be multiple coppies of the same dragon/weapon on either team and the imbalenced combinations I mentioned above means that the game is pretty much decided before it even starts, which is very bad game design.Now as I said above multiple maps with one map being in rotation at a time, the map to be put into rotation is selected by the comunity via an in-game poll. So, four very different maps, sounds extensive for a MOBA right?  However practically no one votees for the standard MOBA map called Towers And Titans and Nether gates hardly ever shows up in the map poll. So there are pretty much only two modes, Balistae ally which is pretty much a single corridor where three high damage balistae bolts are shot from each side every couple of minutes. The other most played mode is Chaos unleashed, wherein you collect gold to summon Chaos who helps you detroy some structures. Having only one map in rotation and knowing which map is in rotation creates some serious balence issues, people can simply pick one of the afformentioned wonder combinations that is suited to that specific map.And know we get on to the Pay to Win aspect of the game. Now the game isn't pay to win as such, practically everything can be unlocked by playing for free, unfortunatly the vast majority of the very best stuff is placed at such a high amount of RNG and luck that it is just not practical to get them as a free to play player, so to get them, a little bit of money is called for.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												When it comes to recommending this game, I would have to say I am more indifferent than yes or no.  I'm just saying yes because to me it can keep one's attention and, all-and-all it is not a bad game, though it has its as flaws, like any other game.I'm not going to give a brief overview of the game, you want to find more official, better detailed ones, because I would probably miss a few important things, I'm just going to tell about my experiences and general opinion of the game.So it has good art, the dragons and weapons are beautifully designed and look great.  The environment looks really good, for me I am not really picky about general looks, but this game has got it down.  The biggest flaw is that it can become tedious and often times boring relatively quickly.  In order to get more dragons, weapons and runes, you must have crystals, the in-game currency.  In singleplayer you get roughly 50-70 crystals a match and for multiplayer and pvp a little more, I can't really say I play singleplayer more then anything.  So let us say I played ten singleplayer matches and got a total of at least 500, at most 700, not bad, but dragons and weapons require a very large amount of crystals to purchase.  Runes are only 150 per pack so that is fine with me, but a 3 pack of weapons is 2500 crystals and a 3 pack of dragons is 5000.  So let us say I am very unlucky and I get 50 crystals per match, I would have to play 100 matches to get a pack, and each match takes about 10-15 minutes, which is quick, but that would take at least 1000 minutes or 16.6 hours.  That is a lot of time.  It used to be you could just buy a dragon or weapon for money, but they got rid of that and made one thing called a titan pack.  You pay 20 dollars and you get one of each tier one dragons, one of each weapons, all the avatar skins, all the dragon skins, Acts 2-4 are now playable (yes, you must pay money to play the story line), all of your rewards are quadrupled for a year, and you will get all new content(like a new dragons or weapons) for a year.  I gotta say, that is actually extremely good.  Before they did this if I wanted to buy all the dragons, weapons, and such it would be more than that, so to me that is an improvement, though now it you only wanted one dragon, you have to pay the whole 20 dollars instead of 3.99 so it can be a double-edged sword of some sort.  Gameplay is good, but it gets very boring, the storyline is okay, but it is more about the multiplayer function.Going into the multiplayer function, I have only played multiplayer matches three times, but in those three times, the teams seemed to be a little lopsided.  But since you really can't have an overpowered dragon, you can increase certain things, but you can still be defeated easily if facing multiple enemies, so it depends on the players and their teamwork, and how well they use their skills too.So in conclusion,- dragons and weapons take a large amount of time to get- multiplayer matches can be lopsided- becomes tedious and boring quickly- you must pay money to play acts 2,3 and 4- you have to buy everything if you only wanted one thing, you must pay $20 if you only wanted to spend $3.99but,- the designs are great- singleplayer is always fun, at least to me- matches are quick- you get free dragons from the acts, all three tiers of a certain dragon, though you need to have certain dragons and weapons to fulfill requirements- you spend money once and you basically get everythingAll-in-all, if you are a casual gamer, this would be a good game, you can put time and effort into it, and you only have to make one purchase and that is it.  I apologize if I left something out, these were the things that I noticed in the game.If I were to give it a rating out of 10, 10 being the best: 6/10

content:
Posted: August 27, 2015
												Unfortunately I cannot recommend this game to new users.  It is a fun game actually, however I am not sure what exactly the developers were thinking pitting low level players/dragons against high level.  It completely ruins the fun of pvp, which is the only place this game is fun past 30 minutes.Pre 1250 rating, it is fun for new players becauase you are paired up against like levels and experience, but once you reach 1250, your pathetic lvl 15 player does not stand a chance.  I mean it is so unbalanced that it becomes moronic.I only about lvl 22 now, but there is no sign of fun anymore, as I have passed 1250, and it is now utterly ridiculous.It goes something like this:You are level 15, with a 1200 rating.  You join pvp, and are paired up against other lvl 1-20s.Then you hit 1250 rating because you are doing well and having fun.You are now paired up against all lvl 40+ with max runes and teir 3+ dragons, gold or higher.Lvl 15, vs all lvl 50s...Who's bright idea was that?  Ruined game.  Only veterans will stay, which is why there is a low population.Strong 'do not purchase' anything, until they resolve that moronic rating system.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												Dragons and Titans used to be an awesome game. After several buffs and nerfs, the game wasn't any longer fun to play. Things that I used to like about D&T that changed: The possibilty to invite up to 5 friends to form a team. Having to use all different dragons in a match. The old controls system without auto-aim. Anything before the Titan Pass.D&T couldn't afford itself after the yearly Titan Pass, for it didn't create any beneficial profit.What D&T should of change is: Starting with the Titan Pass (Same price for a month is more than enough). Remove all Runes (stones collected within the matches), since this allows players to easily use hacks and sometimes stay low profile, and as well helps to keep the abilities of the dragons balanced. Remove the use of repeated dragons in a match. Weekly updates, including at least 1 weapon or 1 dragon. At least 3 Moderators per chat (since not all are always able to be online). Weekly developer or admin visits so players notice the interest of the D&T team towards them.And last but not least, team XP in matches, instead of individual (This will give players a more pleasent and friendly match, since it will encourage all to assist for a common cause).Some new ideas:Replacing the collection of stones for Gold pieces to buy some upgrade for their weapons/dragons with a prior limit set, within the match. The upgrades could either have just a few levels but several type that does not mess the balance in match, such as ''Returning to hoard ability cooldown'', ''Short protective shield for teammates'', ''Dashing a small distance'', and stuff like that.Anyways, there are many things that can be changed to make the game not just as good as it used to be, but greater. Lets not forget the improvements keep players interested, but every change must to be properly debated between D&T team, in order to avoid colliding every feature or element in the game.At the end, there is far too much that can be improved in Dragons and Titans, but the income must to be well thought, that way the D&T team will always feel excited to work with such awesome game. The concept that this game handled is very insteresting and satifying, specially to those who love dragons. But if anyone wants the players to return to this game, a lot has to be done and responsabilities to be assumed. Thanks D&T for so many fun moments and to allow me to meet some of the coolest and easy going people to play with.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 7
												I like the game a lot, it has a fair to wide variety of dragons/weapons you may choose from. Each dragon/weapons has its own unique attacks, however, I will complain that I don't feel certain dragons/weapons are balanced out in a fair way. The game has 4 different maps, and a voting system for which map you would like next after a 25-30 minutes time period. Some maps seems to be a bit laggy, and the servers are down (for multiplayer) sometimes, which can be frustrating, but it's a pleasure to play versus your friends, rivals, and even enemies. Runes also make this game interesting, allowing your dragon to gain small buffs that overall make a huge impact the more you level up in battle. This adds a nice complexity to the game, allowing you to easily twist and turn past a few of your dragon's/weapon's weaknesses, or to allow you to try and make it slightly less of a weakness. The rating system is a nice feature, making so you don't play against newer players, adding challenge, but also making it so that they don't get creamed and can learn a few steps at a time of how the game works. While the game is no longer in developement, I think it'd be nice if it was. One last thing, it would be nice to have a way to gain more crystals (the currency in the game) other than buying the titan pass, which gives you 4x crystals, but only for 1 year. I think making it so you can gain crystals in a faster manner (with either the titan pass's 4x crystals no longer working or if you can't/haven't gotten the titan pass). I've heard complaints about not getting very many crystals after a match, making it so you must grind (which is very annoying) Singleplayer or Multiplayer. With the game no longer in developement and the fact it has "died" a quite a bit, people think the $25 for the titan pass is no longer worth it.I do really enjoy this game though, and I myself don't want to give up on it. Hope the devs decide to go back to it and give it a little more love  <3~DragonFire

												For those that can't take the complexity and seriousness of games like Dota 2, Smite, or LOL, this is a game for you. It's very simple and is easy to learn. The overal gameplay is fantastic, with good graphics, plenty of dragons and weapons, and amazing maps and modes. However, the only setback is the community. Waiting for a match takes a while, some people are jerks, and when you just start out, finding players at your rank are hard.
